articles.headline: Profit Data May Explain U.S. Gloom
articles.snippet: Corporate profits earned in the United States rose much more rapidly from 2005 through 2007 than had been earlier reported, making the subsequent fall seem even more precipitous.
articles.abstract: Corporate profits earned in the United States rose much more rapidly from 2005 through 2007 than had been earlier reported, making the subsequent fall seem even more precipitous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate profits earned in the United States rose much more rapidly from 2005 through 2007 than had been earlier reported, making the subsequent fall seem even more precipitous, government figures showed Thursday.

articles.headline: China’s Ambition Soars to High-Tech Industry
articles.snippet: No longer content with low-skilled manufacturing, Chinese companies are trying to move up the value chain.
articles.abstract: No longer content with low-skilled manufacturing, Chinese companies are trying to move up the value chain.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  Few people have heard of the BYD Corporation  BYD for Build Your Dream  but this little-known company has grown into the world’s second-largest battery producer in less than a decade of existence. Now it plans to make a great leap forward: “We’d like to make a green energy car, a plug-in,” said Paul Lin, a BYD marketing executive. “We think we can do that.”

articles.headline: Automakers Drop Leases as Their Losses Mount
articles.snippet: With consumers flocking to smaller cars, Detroit’s automakers are taking huge losses on the leases that once fueled the boom in trucks and S.U.V.’s.
articles.abstract: With consumers flocking to smaller cars, Detroit’s automakers are taking huge losses on the leases that once fueled the boom in trucks and S.U.V.’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The glory days of automotive leasing are sputtering out, along with the value of used trucks and sport utility vehicles.

articles.headline: Pakistanis Aided Attack in Kabul, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Pakistan’s spy service helped plan the bombing of India’s embassy.
articles.abstract: U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Pakistan’s spy service helped plan the bombing of India’s embassy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American intelligence agencies have concluded that members of Pakistan’s powerful spy service helped plan the deadly July 7 bombing of India’s embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, according to United States government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: High Fuel Costs Delay Airplane Orders
articles.snippet: Despite a multiyear backlog of airplane orders at both Airbus and Boeing, aircraft manufacturers are seeing troubling signs among their customers.
articles.abstract: Despite a multiyear backlog of airplane orders at both Airbus and Boeing, aircraft manufacturers are seeing troubling signs among their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Emirates airline’s gigantic A380 aircraft glides into Kennedy International Airport on Friday, Airbus executives will breathe a sigh of relief at seeing their flagship jet complete its maiden American journey.

articles.headline: More Arrows Seen Pointing to a Recession
articles.snippet: The American economy slowed from April to June, while numbers for the last three months of 2007 were revised downward to show a contraction.
articles.abstract: The American economy slowed from April to June, while numbers for the last three months of 2007 were revised downward to show a contraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy expanded more slowly than expected from April to June, the government reported Thursday, while numbers for the last three months of 2007 were revised downward to show a contraction  the first official slide backward since the last recession in 2001.

articles.headline: McCain Camp Says Obama Is Playing ‘Race Card’
articles.snippet: As the tone of the contest sharpened, the exchange injected racial politics front and center into the campaign.
articles.abstract: As the tone of the contest sharpened, the exchange injected racial politics front and center into the campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla.  Senator John McCain’s campaign accused Senator Barack Obama on Thursday of playing “the race card,” citing his remarks that Republicans would try to scare voters by pointing out that he “doesn’t look like all those other presidents on the dollar bills.”
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Michael Powell

articles.headline: Thain’s Change: From Assurance to Desperation
articles.snippet: Is the fear that John A. Thain, chief of Merrill Lynch, showed in dumping securities for pennies on the dollar an indication that the stock market bottom has been reached?
articles.abstract: Is the fear that John A. Thain, chief of Merrill Lynch, showed in dumping securities for pennies on the dollar an indication that the stock market bottom has been reached?
articles.lead_paragraph: From cockiness to capitulation. From distinction to desperation. From pride to panic.

articles.headline: Fed Fears Wage Spiral That Is Little in Evidence
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s policy makers assume that people eventually demand and get higher pay, but they differ sharply on how quickly that pressure could emerge.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s policy makers assume that people eventually demand and get higher pay, but they differ sharply on how quickly that pressure could emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: The surges this year in oil and food prices could not have come at a worse moment for the typical American worker, who has not had a raise to speak of in this decade.

articles.headline: Once Dumped, ImClone Soars
articles.snippet: If they only had been more patient investors of ImClone Systems, Martha Stewart and others might have done just fine, and avoided jail time.
articles.abstract: If they only had been more patient investors of ImClone Systems, Martha Stewart and others might have done just fine, and avoided jail time.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the most celebrated insider-trading scandals of the last decade, sending Martha Stewart and her Merrill Lynch stock broker to prison, along with the chairman of a highflying biotechnology company whose social climbing had made him a boldface name.
